<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 323, 390, 336]]<|/det|>
# READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 352, 828, 366]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 369, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 386, 327, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 402, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 285, 463]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 465, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 495, 589, 509]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 510, 606, 524]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 541, 606, 555]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 557, 756, 571]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 573, 440, 587]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 589, 907, 618]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 865, 729, 879]]<|/det|>
This document consists of 3 printed pages and 1 blank page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|> The distance of a student's home from college, correct to the nearest kilometre, was recorded for each of 55 students. The distances are summarised in the following table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[171, 114, 868, 163]]<|/det|>

Number of students18138124
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 175, 881, 193]]<|/det|> Dominic is asked to draw a histogram to illustrate the data. Dominic's diagram is shown below. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 212, 833, 632]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 650, 541, 668]]<|/det|> Give two reasons why this is not a correct histogram. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 650, 920, 668]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 695, 92, 713]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 695, 920, 745]]<|/det|> A factory produces flower pots. The base diameters have a normal distribution with mean \(14\mathrm{cm}\) and standard deviation \(0.52\mathrm{cm}\). Find the probability that the base diameters of exactly 8 out of 10 randomly chosen flower pots are between \(13.6\mathrm{cm}\) and \(14.8\mathrm{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 728, 920, 745]]<|/det|> [5] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 774, 92, 792]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 774, 920, 808]]<|/det|> In a large consignment of mangoes, \(15\%\) of mangoes are classified as small, \(70\%\) as medium and \(15\%\) as large. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 821, 153, 838]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 820, 920, 854]]<|/det|> Yue-chen picks 14 mangoes at random. Find the probability that fewer than 12 of them are medium or large. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 866, 158, 884]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 866, 920, 900]]<|/det|> Yue-chen picks \(n\) mangoes at random. The probability that none of these \(n\) mangoes is small is at least 0.1. Find the largest possible value of \(n\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 883, 920, 900]]<|/det|> [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Barry weighs 20 oranges and 25 lemons. For the oranges, the mean weight is \(220 \text{g}\) and the standard deviation is \(32 \text{g}\). For the lemons, the mean weight is \(118 \text{g}\) and the standard deviation is \(12 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 120, 154, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 120, 460, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the mean weight of the 45 fruits.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 152, 156, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 151, 920, 203]]<|/det|>
The individual weights of the oranges in grams are denoted by \(x_{o}\), and the individual weights of the lemons in grams are denoted by \(x_{l}\). By first finding \(\Sigma x_{o}^{2}\) and \(\Sigma x_{l}^{2}\), find the variance of the weights of the 45 fruits.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 186, 920, 203]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 230, 97, 249]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 230, 146, 249]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 230, 920, 265]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) is normally distributed with mean 82 and standard deviation 7.4. Find the value of \(q\) such that \(\mathrm{P}(82 - q < X < 82 + q) = 0.44\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 250, 920, 267]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 277, 144, 295]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 277, 920, 312]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(Y\) is normally distributed with mean \(\mu\) and standard deviation \(\sigma\). It is given that \(5\mu = 2\sigma^2\) and that \(\mathrm{P}(Y < \frac{1}{2}\mu) = 0.281\). Find the values of \(\mu\) and \(\sigma\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 294, 920, 312]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 341, 96, 359]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 341, 153, 359]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 341, 920, 375]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different ways that the 9 letters of the word AGGREGATE can be arranged in a line if the first letter is R.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 355, 920, 375]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 387, 153, 405]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 387, 920, 421]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different ways that the 9 letters of the word AGGREGATE can be arranged in a line if the 3 letters G are together, both letters A are together and both letters E are together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 418, 920, 437]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 448, 151, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 448, 920, 498]]<|/det|>
The letters G, R and T are consonants and the letters A and E are vowels. Find the number of different ways that the 9 letters of the word AGGREGATE can be arranged in a line if consonants and vowels occur alternately.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 482, 920, 500]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 511, 151, 530]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 511, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different selections of 4 letters of the word AGGREGATE which contain exactly 2 Gs or exactly 3 Gs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 528, 920, 546]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 572, 96, 592]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 572, 883, 591]]<|/det|>
Dayo chooses two digits at random, without replacement, from the 9-digit number 113 333 555.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 604, 153, 622]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 604, 609, 622]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the two digits chosen are equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 604, 920, 622]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 635, 151, 653]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 635, 667, 653]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that one digit is a 5 and one digit is not a 5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 635, 920, 653]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 666, 153, 684]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 666, 920, 698]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the first digit Dayo chose was a 5, given that the second digit he chose is not a 5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 682, 920, 700]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 713, 151, 730]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 713, 920, 746]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) is the number of 5s that Dayo chooses. Draw up a table to show the probability distribution of \(X\).
